questions.text: All of the following are clinical indicators of potential ongoing bleeding in torso trauma except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A decreasing respiratory rate is not a typical response to ongoing bleeding and may instead suggest respiratory fatigue or central nervous system depression, not active hemorrhage compensation.

In cases of torso trauma, ongoing bleeding can occur from five major sites, remembered as "one on the floor and four more":

  • External bleeding(the "floor")
  • Chest
  • Abdomen (including retroperitoneum)
  • Pelvis
  • Extremities

Clinical indicators of potential ongoing bleeding in torso trauma include:

  • Physiological signs:
    • Increasing respiratory rate(Option A ruled out)
    • Increasing pulse rate
    • Falling blood pressure(Option D ruled out)
    • Rising serum lactate(Option B ruled out)
  • Anatomical indicators include:
    • Visible bleeding
    • Injury in close proximity to major vessels
    • Penetrating injury with a retained missile

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the evaluation of a patient with a chest injury is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Thoracic Multidetector CT Angiography (MDCTA)is now the standard approach for chest injury evaluation, offering detailed visualization of the chest wall, vasculature, pleural spaces, and lung parenchyma.
  • Chest radiography, not CT chest, is almost universally performed during initial assessment of patients at risk for thoracic injuries. (Option A ruled out)

  • Thoracic MDCTA is unreliable for pericardial evaluation due to cardiac motion artifact. (Option C ruled out)

Chest CT has low sensitivity for the diagnosis of rib fractures
A hemothorax that does not resolve after tube thoracostomy may require thoracoscopic drainage and decortication
A chest tube may be safely removed when output is <50 mL over the prior 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of thoracic injury is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A retained hemothorax that is not adequately evacuated by a chest tube may require early surgical intervention, such as Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS)for drainage and decortication, to prevent complications.
  • A hemothorax visible on upright chest X-ray represents ~400-500 mL of blood and should be evacuated with thoracostomy.
  • Occult pneumothorax, defined as visible on CT but not on chest X-ray, can be managed with observation and repeat chest radiograph after 12-24 hours in stable patients without respiratory compromise. (Option A ruled out)
  • Chest CT is highly sensitive for detecting rib fractures, pleural air/blood, flail segments, displaced ribs, and sternal fractures, and may guide chest wall reconstruction. (Option B ruled out)
  • Chest tubes may be safely removed once the pleural space is evacuated, the tube is on underwater seal, and drainage is <300 mL in the prior 24 hours, not <50 mL. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient with a suspected penetrating cardiac injury develops cardiovascular collapse and requires an immediate emergency department thoracotomy. What is the standard surgical incision for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For cardiac injuries that cause cardiovascular collapse, a left anterolateral thoracotomy is performed in the emergency department and may be extended to a contralateral ("clamshell") incision if needed.

When the patient is stable and time permits, cardiac injuries are best approached through a median sternotomy.

Explanation of other options:

Left posterolateral thoracotomy (Option B): This is a standard incision for elective procedures on the left lung, esophagus, or descending aorta. It requires placing the patient in the lateral decubitus position and takes longer to perform, making it unsuitable for an unstable patient requiring immediate cardiac access.

Right anterolateral thoracotomy (Option C): This incision provides access to the right lung, hilum, and right-sided mediastinal structures. It does not provide adequate access to the left ventricle, which is the most commonly injured chamber. It may be used as an extension of a left-sided incision (creating a "clamshell" thoracotomy) if right-sided injury is suspected.

Right posterolateral thoracotomy (Option D): Similar to the left posterolateral approach, this is used for elective procedures on the right chest and is inappropriate for an emergency thoracotomy for cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the chest radiograph below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given chest X-ray shows a gas-filled viscus (stomach) with air–fluid levels in the left hemithorax, confirming herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. This is diagnostic of a left diaphragmatic rupture.

Radiographic features of diaphragmatic injury:

  • Presence of gastric bubble or bowel loops in thorax
  • Air-fluid levelin the left hemithorax
  • Elevated or obscured hemidiaphragm contour
  • Mediastinal shift to opposite side in large herniations
  • NG tube (if placed) seen coiled within the thorax confirms stomach herniation

Left-sided injuries are more common than right-sided, as the liver provides protection to the right diaphragm. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of Other Options:

Lower esophageal injury (Option C): Esophageal injury presents with pneumomediastinum, pleural effusion, or hydropneumothorax, not a gas-filled stomach in the thorax.

Right bronchial injury (Option D): This is incorrect as the pathology is on the left side. A major bronchial injury would typically present with a massive pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema, and potentially a "fallen lung" sign, none of which are the primary finding here.

choices.text: Diaphragmatic injuries can bleed significantly from branches of the thoracic artery that can be exposed at the edges of the tear
Nonabsorbable synthetic materials can be used to reconstruct the diaphragm in clean surgical fields but should be avoided in contaminated settings
Closure is performed with a single layer of nonabsorbable suture incorporating large full-thickness bites of healthy diaphragmatic tissue
A peripheral detachment of the diaphragm from the wall of the torso can be repaired by reinserting the injured tissue one or two interspaces superior

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the management of a diaphragmatic injury except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Significant hemorrhage from the edges of a diaphragmatic tear originates from branches of the phrenic artery, not the thoracic artery.

Management of Diaphragmatic Injury:

  • Diaphragmatic injuries are typically repaired by debriding nonviable tissue and then closing the defect. The diaphragm exhibits enough redundancy for all but the largest defects to be closed primarily.
  • Closure is performed with a single layer of nonabsorbable sutureincorporating large full-thickness bites of healthy diaphragmatic tissue. (Option C ruled out)
  • It is important to obtain hemostasis because diaphragmatic injuries can bleed significantly from branches of the phrenic artery that can be exposed at the edges of the tear.
  • Large areas of tissue loss are rare in traumatic rupture, but when present, may require reconstruction with a prosthetic.
  • Nonabsorbable synthetic materialscan be used to reconstruct the diaphragm in clean surgical fields but should be avoided in the setting of contamination. (Option B ruled out)
  • A peripheral detachmentof the diaphragm from the wall of the torso can be repaired by reinserting the injured tissue one or two interspaces superior. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect regarding CXR in thoracic injury except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A small to moderate hemothorax can be radiographically occult, as up to 300 mL of blood may pool behind the dome of the diaphragm and remain invisible on an erect CXR.
  • In penetrating injury, an erect CXR is preferred over supine, as it best detects small pneumothorax, fluid meniscus, air-fluid level, or free subdiaphragmatic air (suggesting hollow viscus perforation). (Option A ruled out)
  • In hemodynamically unstable patients or when spinal injury is suspected, an anteroposterior (AP) supine CXR is the standard initial investigation, as it provides information on tracheal deviation, lung and mediastinal pathology, and skeletal injury; PA view requires stability and upright positioning. (Option C ruled out)
  • Lower rib fractures are associated with liver or spleen injury; fractures of any rib, regardless of location, may cause lung parenchymal or thoracic wall vascular injury, leading to pneumothorax, hemothorax, or lung contusion. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following injuries are considered immediately life-threatening except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
In the primary survey of a trauma patient, chest injuries are classified into immediately life-threatening and potentially life-threatening conditions.

A ruptured diaphragm is a serious injury but is classified as potentially life-threatening, meaning it may not cause immediate death but can lead to severe complications if missed.

The other options are all immediately life-threatening injuries that must be identified and managed during the primary survey (the "A-B-C's") to prevent imminent death.

choices.text: A tension pneumothorax develops when a 'one-way valve' air leak occurs from the lung or chest wall
The mediastinum is displaced to the opposite side, decreasing venous return and compressing the opposite lung
Treatment should always be started after radiological confirmation
A large-bore cannula should be rapidly inserted into the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding tension pneumothorax except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency diagnosed clinically based on its dramatic presentation of restlessness, tachypnea, and dyspnea. Therefore, life-saving treatment must never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation.

Tension pneumothorax:

  • The underlying pathophysiology involves a 'one-way valve' air leak that traps air in the pleural space, completely collapsing the affected lung. (Option A ruled out)
  • This trapped air causes the mediastinum to be displaced to the opposite side, which critically decreases venous return to the heart and compresses the contralateral lung, leading to obstructive shock. (Option B ruled out)
  • The immediate life-saving intervention is decompression, which is initially performed by the rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula into the second intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line, followed by a definitive chest tube. (Option D ruled out)
  • Clinical examination reveals hyper-resonance and decreased or absent breath sounds on the affected side; tracheal deviation is a late and unreliable sign.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Contralateral mediastinal and tracheal shift
    • Ipsilateral hemidiaphragm flattening or inversion
    • Widening of the intercostal spaces
    • Complete collapse of the ipsilateral lung
    • Hyperlucent hemithorax without lung markings

choices.text: Its clinical presentation is similar to tension pneumothorax
The central venous pressure is always elevated
eFAST is a key diagnostic tool

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding pericardial tamponade except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pericardial tamponade with severe hypovolemia, CVP may appear normal or low, as volume loss masks the typical elevation.

Pericardial Tamponade:

  • Clinical features resemble tension pneumothorax: progressive cyanosis, tachycardia, agitation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Diagnosis: eFASTcan identify pericardial fluid and concurrent intraperitoneal fluid. (Option D ruled out)
  • Hemodynamics: CVP may remain normal/low if hypovolemia coexists.
  • Management: Pericardiocentesis provides temporary relief but carries a high complication risk; definitive treatment is prompt surgical intervention. (Option C ruled out)

If the chest wall opening exceeds one-third of the trachea's diameter, air will be preferentially drawn through the defect

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding an open pneumothorax is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct initial management for an open pneumothorax is to promptly close the defect with a sterile occlusive dressing taped on only three sides.

Open Pneumothorax:

  • Definition: Sucking chest wound due to large open chest wall defect → pleural cavity communicates with atmosphere.
  • Critical Size: The pathophysiology involves a large defect, typically >3 cmor >2/3 tracheal diameter → air preferentially enters through wound. (Options A & B ruled out)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Loss of negative intrapleural pressure → lung collapse
    • Air accumulates in pleural cavity(not lung) (Option C ruled out)
    • Risk of tension pneumothoraxif flap-valve effect occurs
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sucking sound from wound
    • Respiratory distress, hypoxia
    • Asymmetric chest movement
  • Initial Management:
    • Occlusive plastic dressing taped on 3 sides(flutter valve)
    • Insert chest tuberemote from wound site
    • Definitive surgical closure of defect

choices.text: This condition usually results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures
It is defined as three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places
To confirm the diagnosis, the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a segment
A chest radiograph (CXR) is the gold standard for diagnosis

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding flail chest except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Flail chest results from blunt thoracic trauma and is defined as three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places, creating a free-floating chest wall segment. (Options A & B ruled out)

  • The diagnosis is primarily clinical, not radiological.
  • Paradoxical respirationis the hallmark sign (Option C ruled out):
    • During inspiration, the flail segment moves inward, reducing lung expansion.
    • During expiration, the segment bulges outward.
  • This leads to impaired ventilation, underlying pulmonary contusion, and hypoxia.
  • CXR can show rib fractures or associated injuries (hemothorax, pneumothorax)but is not the gold standard.
  • CT chest with 3D reconstructionis considered the gold standard for diagnosis and assessment of severity.

questions.text: A patient involved in a severe deceleration injury has the following chest radiograph (Image A) and subsequent angiogram (Image B) performed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The combination of a widened mediastinum on the initial chest radiograph (Image A) and the definitive finding of a contained rupture on the subsequent angiogram (Image B) are classic signs of a thoracic aortic disruption.

This is a highly lethal injury, most commonly occurring at the aortic isthmus just distal to the left subclavian artery, and is typically caused by high-energy deceleration mechanisms. A widened mediastinum on a chest X-ray is the most common initial finding that raises suspicion for this injury.

Explanation of other options:

Pericardial tamponade (Option B): This diagnosis is best made with an eFAST scan showing fluid in the pericardial sac. While the heart silhouette might be enlarged on a chest X-ray, the key finding of a widened mediastinum due to a hematoma is specific to the aortic injury shown.

Traumatic thrombosis (Option C): While thrombosis can be a component of an aortic injury, "disruption" is the more accurate and comprehensive diagnosis that accounts for the wall defect and periaortic hematoma causing the widened mediastinum seen in the images.

Avulsion of the aortic root (Option D): This is an even more lethal injury that occurs at the base of the heart. The classic location for traumatic aortic disruption seen in survivors is the aortic isthmus, which is what the angiogram findings would confirm, not the aortic root.

choices.text: Clamping the ascending aorta to cut off blood supply to the heart and brain

questions.text: All of the following are primary aims of an Emergency Department Thoracotomy (EDT) except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Emergency department thoracotomy (EDT) is performed in patients with life-threatening thoracic injuries, especially after penetrating trauma.

The aim of EDT is to perform:

  • Internal cardiac massage to restore circulation in cardiac arrest. (Option A ruled out)
  • Control of haemorrhage from cardiac, pulmonary, or other intrathoracic sources. (Option C ruled out)
  • Control of massive air leak, e.g., from major bronchial injury or tension pneumothorax. (Option D ruled out)
  • Clamping of the thoracic aorta (descending thoracic aorta, not ascending aorta) to preserve blood supply to the heart and brain while temporarily cutting off distal arterial flow in a moribund patient with major distal penetrating injury.

choices.text: If CPR has been ongoing for >5 mins in a patient without an endotracheal tube
If CPR has been ongoing for >10 mins in a patient who is intubated
In a patient with blunt trauma who showed no signs of life at the scene
All of the above are correct

questions.text: Which of the following situation(s) is/are considered an indication that an Emergency Department Thoracotomy (EDT) would be futile?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An Emergency Department Thoracotomy (EDT) is a highly invasive, last-resort procedure. To avoid performing a non-beneficial intervention, specific criteria for futility have been established.

The recognized situations where EDT is futile include:

  • CPR for > 5 minutesin the absence of endotracheal intubation.
  • CPR for > 10 minutes despite endotracheal intubation.
  • Blunt trauma when there have been no signs of life at the scene.

questions.text: What is the AAST grade for a subcapsular hematoma involving 67% of the spleen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The AAST (American Association for the Surgery of Trauma) spleen injury scale classifies splenic injuries based on extent and depth of hematoma or laceration.

The criteria for Grade III include a subcapsular hematoma that covers >50% of the surface area or is expanding.

questions.text: Hepatic parenchymal disruption involving 50% of a hepatic lobe is classified as which grade of AAST liver injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The AAST (American Association for the Surgery of Trauma) liver injury scale classifies liver injuries based on extent of parenchymal disruption, haematoma size, and vascular involvement.

  • Grade IV is defined as laceration with parenchymal disruption involving 25-75% of a hepatic lobe or 1-3 Couinaud segments in a single lobe.
  • Lower grades involve smaller subcapsular haematomas or superficial lacerations, while higher grades (V-VI) involve >75% of a lobe, multiple segments, juxtahepatic venous injury, or hepatic avulsion.

choices.text: It controls inflow from the portal triad
It can be performed by direct compression with a soft clamp
It reduces arterial and portal venous inflow to the liver
It also controls bleeding from the inferior vena cava

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the Pringle's maneuver except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Pringle's maneuver is a hemostatic technique involving temporary occlusion of the portal triad (hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct) within the hepatoduodenal ligament.
  • This is commonly performed with a soft clamp or digital pressure. (Option B ruled out)
  • Its primary purpose is to control inflow tothe liver by stopping blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein. Therefore, it correctly controls inflow from the portal triad and reduces arterial and portal venous inflow. (Options A & C ruled out)
  • The maneuver's limitation is that it does not affect the liver's venous outflow. It cannot control hemorrhage from the hepatic veins or the retrohepatic inferior vena cava (IVC).
  • If bleeding persists after the maneuver is applied, the source is presumed to be from the hepatic veins or the IVC.

choices.text: The pancreas should classically be treated with conservative surgery and closed suction drainage
Injuries to the pancreatic body and tail are treated by closed suction drainage alone, or with distal pancreatectomy if the main duct is involved
A Whipple's procedure is commonly performed as an emergency procedure for pancreatic trauma
Pyloric exclusion can be used to minimize pancreatic enzyme stimulation

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding the management of pancreatic injury except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The management of pancreatic trauma is guided by the principle of using the least complex intervention possible. Classically, the pancreas is treated with conservative surgery and wide, closed suction drainage. (Option A ruled out)
  • For injuries affecting the body and tail (left of the superior mesenteric vessels), treatment is closed suction drainage alone, with a distal pancreatectomy reserved for cases where the main pancreatic duct is involved. (Option B ruled out)
  • In cases of combined severe pancreatic and duodenal injury, pyloric exclusion can be performed to divert gastric contents and minimize pancreatic stimulation. (Option D ruled out)
  • In contrast, a Whipple's procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy)is a highly complex operation with a very high mortality rate in the acute trauma setting. It is rarely indicated and should not be performed as an emergency procedure. For severe injuries to the pancreatic head, a damage control approach with packing and drainage is the standard of care, with definitive reconstruction performed later once the patient is stable

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for radiological assessment in suspected renal trauma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Radiological imaging is warranted in renal trauma when history or clinical features suggest a significant risk of injury.

The indications for radiological assessment in suspected renal trauma are:

  • Penetrating injury to the abdomen, flank, or lower chest.
  • Gross hematuria following trauma.
  • Shock associated with microscopic hematuria(systolic BP < 90 mmHg).
  • Pediatric patients with any hematuria, as their kidneys are anatomically lower and less protected.

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect regarding abdominal injury except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:
In abdominal trauma, bowel injury, especially when it results in perforation, is a surgical emergency. A perforated bowel can rapidly lead to peritonitis, sepsis, and multiorgan failure if untreated. Therefore, urgent definitive surgical management is required to repair the injury, prevent contamination, and control infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Duodenal injuries are often associated with renal injury (Option A):

Duodenal injuries are more commonly associated with pancreatic trauma because of their close anatomical relationship in the retroperitoneum.

In children, all patients with splenic injury require operative management (Option B):

In pediatric patients, non-operative management is preferred for most splenic injuries, provided the child is hemodynamically stable. Operative intervention is only indicated in cases of persistent instability or ongoing bleeding.

Kidney and urinary tract injury is best diagnosed with USG (Option C):

While ultrasound can detect gross renal injuries or free fluid, the investigation of choice for stable patients is contrast-enhanced CT scan, as it provides detailed anatomical information.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about airway burn injury except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inhaled steam causes subglottic (not supraglottic) burns.

Airway burn injuries can result from inhalation of hot gases, steam, smoke particles, and chemical irritants.

Dangers of smoke, hot gas or steam inhalation:

  • Inhaled hot gases cause supraglottic airway burns and laryngeal edema. (Option A ruled out)
  • Inhaled steam causes subglottic burns and loss of respiratory epithelium.
  • Inhaled smoke particles cause chemical alveolitis and respiratory failure. (Option C ruled out)
  • Inhaled poisons, such as carbon monoxide, can cause metabolic poisoning.
  • Full-thickness burns to the chest cause mechanical blockage of rib movement, impairing ventilation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: In a patient with what percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) burned does the inflammatory reaction cause fluid loss in vessels remote from the burn injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Burn injuries trigger an inflammatory response that increases vascular permeability and causes fluid to shift from the intravascular to the extravascular space. This fluid loss predominantly occurs during the first 36 hours post-injury and includes water, solutes, and proteins but not red blood cells.

  • In small burns (<10-15% TBSA), the inflammatory response is largely localised to the burn area with minimal systemic effect.
  • As the burn size approaches 10-15% TBSA, the intravascular fluid loss becomes significant enough to risk circulatory shock.
  • However, once the burn area exceeds 25% TBSA, the inflammatory response becomes systemic, causing increased vascular permeability and fluid loss not only at the burn site but also in vessels remote from the injury, which exacerbates hypovolemia and shock.
  • This systemic vascular leak is why accurate measurement of TBSA burned is crucial to guide appropriate fluid resuscitation and management.

TBSA can be estimated using the Wallace Rule of Nines and Lund & Browder chart.

choices.text: If intubation is delayed, cricothyroidotomy may be required

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the initial management of airway burns?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Airway burns pose a significant risk of airway edema and obstruction due to thermal injury and ensuing inflammation. The initial management must focus on securing the airway promptly.

  • Early elective intubation is considered safest to prevent airway compromise, as swelling and edema rapidly progress in the hours after injury.
  • Delaying intubation risks severe edema, making subsequent intubation very difficult or impossible.
  • In cases where intubation is not possible due to severe airway obstruction, readiness for an emergency cricothyroidotomyis essential to maintain oxygenation.

questions.text: Fat burn is which kind of burn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Fat burns typically involve damage extending into the deep dermal layer and can sometimes progress to full-thickness burns. This is because fat tissue lies beneath the dermis, and exposure to hot fat causes deeper injury compared to superficial scalds.

Unlike superficial burns that affect only the epidermis and upper dermis, fat burns often cause deep dermal necrosis due to the high heat retention of fat.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding escharotomy incision placement is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lower limb escharotomy incisions are placed medially, posterior to the ankle, not laterally.

Escharotomy is a crucial surgical procedure performed to relieve the constriction caused by full-thickness circumferential burns, preventing ischemia and compartment syndrome.

  • Escharotomy incisions must extend beyond the edges of the burnt skin to ensure complete decompression.
  • Bleeding vessels should be controlled with diathermy.
  • Postoperative limb elevation and hemostatic dressings reduce swelling and bleeding.

questions.text: Name the topical agent used in the treatment of burn wounds that reduces cell-mediated immunosuppression.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Silver sulphadiazine and cerium nitrate combination is a useful topical agent, especially for full-thickness burns. Cerium nitrate forms a sterile eschar on the burned skin and has been shown to reduce cell-mediated immunosuppression that occurs after burns, particularly in elderly patients. This agent not only provides antimicrobial protection but also boosts cell-mediated immunity, an important factor in burn wound healing and prevention of systemic infections.

Explanation of Other Options:

1% silver sulphadiazine cream (Option A) offers broad-spectrum antibacterial prophylaxis, effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, but does not reduce immunosuppression.

0.5% silver nitrate solution (Option B) is effective as prophylaxis against Pseudomonas colonization but less active against some gram-negative aerobes compared to silver sulphadiazine. Requires reapplication every 2-4 hours due to washout and causes black staining of surrounding materials. No immunomodulatory effects.

Mafenide acetate cream (Option C) is commonly used in the US as a 5% topical solution. It is effective against many burn wound pathogens but is painful to apply and has been associated with metabolic acidosis. It does not reduce immunosuppression.
